basic.description:
Overview of mammalian development, emphasizing the cellular and molecular mechanisms that direct embryogenesis. The first 2/3 of the course consists of lectures on gastrulation, neurulation, establishment of the body axes, differentiation, sex determination, limb development, and organogenesis. The last 1/3 of the course involves student seminar presentations and group discussions of current topics in developmental biology and teratology. Offered jointly with ANAT-417*. Students submit a major essay and give a seminar from a selected list of topics.  Three hours of lectures/seminars per week. Winter term. C.W. Reifel
PREREQUISITE: ANAT-416/ANAT-816*, or BMED-816*, or permission of the Department. EXCLUSION: ANAT-817*
basic.subject: BMED
basic.title: Mammalian Embryonic Development
